tit.j: 国学 (律令制の教育機関)
tit.e: Kokugaku (Educational institutes under the Ritsuryo system)

sen.j: 国学（こくがく）とは、律令制において、官人育成のために令制国に設置された地方教育機関。
sen.e: The term Kokugaku means educational institutes established, with the aim of nurturing officials, at each province under the Ritsuryo system (the system of centralized government based on the Riysuryo code).

sen.j: 大宝律令によって設置が定められ、各国の国府に1校の併設が義務付けられた。
sen.e: Their establishment was legislated by the Taiho Ritsuryo and each province was obliged to establish one Kokugaku at its kokufu (provincial capital).

sen.j: 入学資格としては郡司の子弟のうち13－16歳の聡明な者とされていたが、場合によっては庶民の子弟の入学を許した。

sen.e: Students were divided into gakusho, candidates for government officials, and isho, candidates for doctors, and the number of students differed depending on the size of province.

sen.e: It is contemlated that their curriculums were almost same with those of daigakuryo (the bureau of education)/tenyakuryo (the bureau of medicine) established by the central government.

sen.j: 757年には中央の制度改革に伴って学生が細分化されて講経生・傅生・医生・針生・天文生・陰陽生・暦算生に分かれた。
sen.e: In the wake of the institutional reforms implemented by the central government in 757, students were further segmented into kogyosho, densho, isho, harisho (students of acupuncture), tenmon no sho (students of astronomy), onmyo no sho (students of onmyo) and rekisansho (students of mathematics).

sen.j: 教官としては各国毎に国博士（くにのはかせ）・国医師（くにのいし）を各1名ずつ置く事が定められていたが、人材難に悩まされて国学が置かれない国や一人の教官が複数国を担当することも珍しくなかった。
sen.e: Although it was set down that a kuni no hakase and a kuni no ishi should be allocated as teachers at each kokugaku, it was not uncommon, because of the difficulty in finding suitable personnel, to see provinces where kokugau was not established or a case where a teacher taught at several provinces.

sen.j: だが、平安時代に入ると律令制度の崩壊とともに国学も衰退し、11世紀に入る頃までにはほぼ消滅した。
sen.e: In association with the collapse of the Ritsuryo system in the Heian period, kokugaku also declined and ceased to exist by the beginning of 11th century.
